pros: Cutting edge research, possibility of publication
cons: Couldn't think of it at the moment

review_title: Great Postdoctoral Experience at Worcester Polytechnic Institute
pros: I recently completed my postdoctoral fellowship at Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI), it was a fulfilling and rewarding experience. WPI has provided me with a rich environment to further my research, develop my skills, and expand my professional network. The mentorship provided by the faculty members at WPI has been exceptional. My supervisor was not only highly knowledgeable in the field but also deeply invested in my success. They provided invaluable guidance, feedback, and encouragement throughout my fellowship, ensuring that I was on the right track, helping me overcome challenges, and actively investing in my career development activities. The regular meetings and discussions with my mentor and fellow postdocs were enriching and pushed me to think critically, enabling me to refine my research methodologies and sharpen my analytical skills.
cons: The only minor downside I experienced during my time at WPI was the relatively low compensation package. However, given the relatively low cost of living in the Worcester area compared to Boston, for example, the expenses offset to average Postdoc salary to some extent.

review_title: Great place to train for industry but low pay for PhD students
job_title: Phd Student Researcher in Worcester, MA
pros: Depending on how much you push to learn more and take classes with top professors (instead of worry about grades, unless you have to), you can learn high end practical knowledge and gain experience with state of the art equipment which apply to a wide variety of industries. I learned from physics, robotics, mechanical, materials, bioengineering and civil departments and worked with many instruments for different projects and almost everyone is supporting and willing to teach or work with you. Of course you have to communicate and link with labs and different scientists to in order to work with them but that’s all part of the PhD journey. It’s a highly valuable experience that trains you for problem solving, you learn all the fundamentals in classes and apply them hands on in lab settings. Just prepare for living a minimal life for 4,5 years or with family support and you can do a lot after PhD. This doesn’t mean that there are a lot of jobs out there for PhDs as it becomes a very specific application, people say tenure track is a stressful path but some like it, and instructors don't get paid enough but have a path, if you get a job in industry you’ll be very successful imo and that depends on the disciplines that you practiced, so just train for something that has a big industry like tech, pharma at this time.
cons: Low pay for PhD researchers, income is number one stress factor (apa, 2015) and PhD researchers could perform better with more benefits

pros: Learned new skills, received mentorship

review_title: WPI is a great place to work. Great people, great students, nice facilities.
pros:
There are lot of great reasons to work at WPI. 
1. The place is filled with very smart and interesting people. 
2. You can sit in on classes with professor permission. I never had one deny me.
3. You can get financial breaks to get a BS or MS
4. Nice athletic facilities
5. Students are a joy.
6. Some of the best conversations I've had in a long time
7. You can participate in research and write papers
8. Pretty campus
9. Free seminars
10. Some time flexibility
11. Decent benefits
cons: Pay is the the worse thing about working in any academic place.  Salaries are about 3/4 what you would expect elsewhere. Since pay is often grant base, it can disappear.

review_title: Has great potential, but not a yet fully realized graduate program.
pros: The first thing that you'll noticed is the small size but still has access to great equipment and instruments.  The location of the school is about 45min from Boston and we have access to the major University's there as well as our close neighbor UMASS Medical School.  The Professors I work with on a whole seem very invested in the the students that they teach and care about their success.
cons: Though it is small in size it doesn't necessarily have the intimacy you would expect.  It feels far more like a job then any sort of mentoring graduate program and their is a huge disparity between what is expected with your teaching assistantship responsibilities from the professors you help and the research professor you also work for.  This causes a lot of unnecessary tension.  Continuing on this point as a graduate student you don't really feel like a part of the institution because I believe this lack of vision exists on several levels.  Don't expect the graduate program to be like the far more developed and successful undergraduate program.

job_title: Peer Learning Assistant in Worcester, MA

cons: Frequent communication difficulties (between professors, students, and TAs)

pros: Great retirement benefits. Flexible work schedules (depending on your manager and job duties). Plenty of paid holidays and generous PTO for salaried employees.
cons:
Leadership is stagnant and consists of a lot of long time employees who made their way up the chain by being the next man in line when somebody moves up or quits. This is great if you just want to get a promotion, but it leads to people being in power with no skills, expertise or outside experience being brought to the organization. When somebody is being replaced, "After an exhaustive nation-wide search", it ends up being the person below them just getting promoted. 
They wont fire people for poor performance, they just keep letting them do a terrible job and negatively impacting those around them. The "Raises" are pathetic for working staff (1%/yr), while upper management will see raises in the tens of thousands. This is especially disturbing for a Non-Profit organization that has leadership with higher salaries than equivalent positions in larger, for-profit companies. Being a Non-Profit, take a look at the publicly available 990 form from the IRS to see for yourself. The student newspaper occasionally publishes these numbers as well.

pros: Nice people, good benefit, flexible schedule
cons: Have to work for a long time

pros: It's a pretty nice university and I really love there
cons: I don't think it has some cons

pros: Great community and colleagues help each other!
cons: None so far. Had a positive experience!

pros: The pay is competitive for the location
cons: Not a lot of graduate student support

pros: Great Office environment. Good benefits
cons: Could be better paid. More support would be great.

review_title: WPI is a good environment to be a teaching/research assistant.
pros: WPI is a relatively good tech school for the area and it's an interesting place to work in IT. The campus is located in an easily accessible location, and most buildings are really beautiful. Computing facilities are state-of-the-art and the atmosphere is quite relaxed most of the time (it is a university after all). The university is expanding quite rapidly, especially in the field of biotechnology and other bio-sciences and there are quite significant grants that go along with it. The school is also generous to employees when it comes to taking classes both at WPI and at other Worcester consortium schools. In most departments management is competent and approachable.
cons: While overall WPI seems like a good place to work, as far as IT jobs are concerned, the pay is probably less than in the industry (but not less than other academic environments). Health benefits haven't been expanded in a while, and there are no health plans for graduate researchers. In general, benefit packages for graduate assistants could be much better (there is no health insurance or any other benefits). Weather conditions on campus also leave a lot to be desired (the school is on a hill and gets a lot of wind and snow in the winter almost every year).

pros: The benefits of working here are great, especially if you are a working and/or single parent.  The one thing I've loved about working her the most is how supportive everyone is of your work life balance.  Being able to use half my sick days a year to take time off for my child has been wonderful.  Additionally, the dependent educational benefits are great.  Health care and other medical insurances are okay.  Most people are genuinely nice here.  Pay here is again just okay, but much better than the other colleges around us.
cons: The benefit are different if you are salaried than if you are hourly.  Still, not bad if you are the hourly, but it is noticeable - especially retirement benefits.  While salaried people get 4 weeks of vacation right away, it will take 10 years of employment for hourly staff to reach the same level.  Raises have been painfully thin the last few years.

review_title: Was a student at WPI and did the federal work study program.
job_title: Work Study, Tutoring Center in Worcester, MA
pros: Overall a very good experience both in working and as a student. WPI's work study jobs are exactly what FWS should be: relevant to your major and accommodating for a student's true number one priority: school. Hours were flexible and very accommodating to a downright busy schedule!
cons: This may have more to do with my hours I had to work more than anything, but for my particular job I felt not a lot happened. I had morning and afternoon classes, thus not a lot of people always showed up in late afternoons and evenings unless big tests loomed on the horizon. On the plus side, I had plenty of time to study for myself on less busy days.

pros:
WPI is one of the ,pst generous schools around when it comes to adjunct and instructor pay.  Professors have a great deal of autonomy in designing their classes.  Fantastic colleagues and really smart and capable students.

Great benefits (downside is pay, see below)
cons:
Lack of prerequisites (school policy) means that you sometimes get  ill prepared students.  The down-side of professor autonomy is that the programs can be a bit disjoint.  All the usual things about academia lagging industry and the usual mixed-message frustration of any large organization be it academic or industry.

Even at WPIs unusually generous level, its pretty hard to support a middle class family on just what one instructor makes.

pros: Academic life, potential to form new connections, as compared to regular colleges, if you want to teach in the STEM field, you will find many students who want to learn the subject.
cons: Top management has turned education into a business. The school exists to appease their students in order to receive favorable reviews. The chief financial officer (in fact all the top brass) are more interested in filling their own pockets than educating students. Case in point, the CFO has a clause written in his agreement that he gets a percentage of the money 'he' saves WPI annually. Remember, he is the one responsible for keeping the numbers....Like most other academic institutes, the college has become 'top heavy'. Too many administrators and the professors are given larger class loads each year and are penalized for not passing/keeping students happy.

review_title: Loved it! Good experience, Not good pay
job_title: ECE Senior Tutor in Worcester, MA
pros: Probably the best department to work for is ECE. Most of the professor seem to really care about their tutors. I really loved working there.
cons:
Workload can overwhelming at times, if you are tutoring a large class with labs.
Department does not pay you more that 10h/week even if you work more, which always happens during finals season.
Also, I am really sorry to say this but pay is to laugh at. It is pretty much a minimum wage job. I realize most students do it for the experience but there are others who actually need the money and they are forced to take other part-time jobs that are not related to their major and which affect negatively their prospective career goals

pros: WPI is truly a community and, although politics are present, it's better than most places. The benefits are good - free tuition at WPI or tuition reimbursement at another school, 403(b) with matching, generous time off (better for salaried employees), and communication is good. All of their employee benefits, including a salary scale are listed on their website.
cons:
The pay is less than in a corporate environment, but that's to be expected in academia. Politics did play a role in the promotion of managers to higher level management; however, there is some room to advance and move into management and/or to make lateral moves. 

Unfortunately, there are are professors and management who generally treat you badly and, due to tenure or a good relationship with upper management, they'll be there forever, but I found it was better here than most places I've worked.

review_title: University undergoing great growth and development, but not sure if students remain #1focus
pros:
Warm, tight knit community with easy communications to the top and laterally
Great opportunities to be innovative and recognized for your contributions
Very easy to be considered for another position within the university
WPi students and faculty are so brilliant and talented, down- to-earth, , it's a wonderful environment
cons:
Fiscally very smart and conservative, but raises do not keep up with insurance increases alone.
Administration is placing new focus in "corporate engagement model."  This has already placed some people in strategic roles who do not seem student focused but corporation- focused. Has many people on faculty and staff concerned.

pros:
- High degree of freedom to explore new ideas and projects while been funded as a research assistant
- Flexible working time, just get all the things done before due dates and you can literally work at home 7 days a week
- No risk of being fired if new ideas turn out to be not so good as expected
- Tons of opportunities after granduation
cons:
- Poor training to the staff, do not expect the school staff always treat you well
- Parking lot management is a nightmare
- As a PhD student, there is no work-life balance in general here. Life is to work, and work for life

review_title: Exciting developments in STEM studies plus project work.
job_title: Marketing Project Manager in Worcester, MA
pros: There are plenty opportunities to learn in emerging fields, and some which combine several major areas of study. The school recognizes that technical talent needs to be paired with the ability to communicate new ideas, and WPI aims for a well-rounded college life, with its new gym, Greek life, counseling and a sustainability focus. Learning sciences, participation in the DOE Solar Decathlon program, and other academics benefit students and the city.
cons: There is some disconnect with the information that's needed to sustain academic levels while marketing the school. It's surprising that no intranet exists and that Web pages, once set up, are not edited centrally.

review_title: sinking ship in IT department, no raises, no hope
pros:
amazing benefits (403b w 11% match)
good healthcare
free cell phone and gym membership
excellent PTO
cons:
-1% raises are a JOKE
-not much room for advancement
-change takes forever
-CIO was hired because of knowing someone in HR. She has an impressive resume otherwise, but I feel like she is not qualified for the job and was picked to please executive management and cut funding to our department
-strong likelihood department will be outsourced in the near future. I would not recommend working here

pros: WPI is a great community for research and learning. The Graduate program in Chemistry and Biochemistry continues to improve. The staff and students have a good working relationship.  The research buildings have great equipment and are very collaborative.
cons: The Chemistry and Biochemistry department is still small, but is continuing to grow. The class offerings are also minimal for Graduate Students, but the department is aware of this.  They are making an effort to offer more options in the future.

pros: It is a simple job and the other employees are pleasant to work with. The management is understanding and always ready to help when questions arise. As federal work study, it is a relief to have a job on campus with short hours of work every week.
cons: The weekly meetings are not always the most exciting, but it is a good chance to learn more about the coworkers and the procedures that go on in the stockroom and in Chemistry and Biochemistry in general.

pros: Great benefits available to employees. Some divisions are great - really depends on the Vice President. The college tries to create a good work environment, especially the HR department.
cons: The work environment below the management level is great. Above manager level research your VP before accepting a job. Some have a revolving door of managers below them. Professional development is very limited and not a priority for administrative staff.

review_title: Students are great, but not the management
pros: The students are fantastic and make the job exciting. There's a lot of opportunity to get involved in the campus community, even as a staff member.
cons: Higher level management isn't exactly qualified to be in their roles. Expectations are set very high without resources to meet expectations or accomplish goals.

review_title: Great place to do your Ph.D.
pros: Really flexible access to labs, very engaged and excited faculty, very nice facilities with extreme operating hours.
cons: It is not a hugely recognizable name, so if you want to go on to teach at a prestigious university or work in a prestigious lab, it might be somewhat limiting.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: The professors are always available if you need help with learning the subject.  Class sizes are mostly small so there is not too much grading.
cons: If you have a large class, grading can be very time consuming.  You may be asked to teach a class you know very little about so you have to learn the material quickly so you can answer undergrads questions.

review_title: Good, smart people, everyone cares for one another & very little 'red tape'
pros: good people, pay well, project based curriculum, it is easy to get a project implemented.  The school is open to new ideas, the departments communicate well, most professors and staff do not leave their job.  Most employees: Professors, staff; and maintenance & service employees have been at WPI for a long time, and it is uncommon to loose them.
cons: smaller school, city is 'okay' but boston is near

pros:
1. Maintain latest software and upgrade out-of-date software on Windows 7.
2. Set lab policies to ensure safety and order.
3. Be able to see what's going on internally.
4. Get paid until you graduate.
cons: There's no downsides for this job, other than there are very few issues occurring throughout the semester, which is a good thing overall, but not good for you if you wished to do maintenance and repairs.

review_title: This school focuses more on undergraduate students.
pros: You can have a solid foundation as an undergraduate. It can help you to hand many basic knowledge about engineering.
cons: This school is too small to have too much money spent on research. Also the research group in this school is too small. It's hard to publish good papers and find good jobs in big company.

review_title: A great job to work while being a student at WPI
pros: Good pay, make new connections with professors and staff, go at your own pace, an overall good experience and a great way to make ends meet while taking classes or during breaks.
cons: Limited growth as an employee - especially if you're a student. It's a small community, and depending on what job you are working and in which department you are in, you may or may not get much exposure to connection opportunities.

review_title: Had a great experience working a GA position
pros:
-worked from home most of the time--only came in for meetings
-very flexible hours
-My boss and coworkers were very nice and easy to work with.
-The job was just very fulfilling. It felt great to be contributing to academic research by ensuring quality software.
cons:
-The fact that it was a part-time job that paid minimum wage meant I was barely making enough money to afford gas and food. 

It was good for what it was--a student job.

pros: In business school they have a tight budget so they don't fund you or offer scholarship but you could work as a graduate assistant while you are doing your graduate studies. Some professors will give you a lot of grading and other assignments depending on the professor.
cons: Time consuming. Its a task to manage school assignments and meetings with the work load the professors will have for you. As a result of which you will be working throughout the week.

job_title: Recreation Center Employee in Worcester, MA
pros: The hours are really flexible and they work around my busy schedule.  As a student there, it made it easy to find time to work.
cons: The pay is not great and there are a lot of students that have the job due to work study.  Other than that it was helpful.

pros: Good retirement plan, Interaction with students is highly rewarding. Flexible schedule. Opportunity to get a education.
cons: Management is only interested in protecting their positions. Decisions are based on politics, not facts or common sense. HR is used as muscle to force those who question management out. Marketing department basically runs the campus. Talents of good people routinely wasted buy incompetent managers.

review_title: Above average place to work and learn
pros: Passionate intelligent people to work with, lots of interesting projects and funding, very dynamic environment. It is a lot of fun and there is a lot of stuff to do and an enormous amount of support for projects
cons: It is a little unstable, there is reasonably high faculty turnover, and the campus is constantly changing.

pros:
Terrific, diverse community
Paid tuition and living wage stipend
Laid back and mostly low-pressure, unless you want to take on a lot more responsibility
cons: Depends on your boss! Working with professors means people with tenure get a little comfortable and do whatever they please, sometimes at your expense.

pros: Great vacation, health and 403B benefits
cons: Poor pay, poor recognition and poor upper level management.

pros: Great benefits.  Very easy commute most of the time.  Parking has improved immensely since the underground parking garage has opened.
cons: The family type of feeling has been replaced by a more corporate watch your back type of attitude across campus. The lower you are in the hierarchy, then the more apt you are to be presumed guilty by the elites et al

pros: It was  a really good experience working at WPI. It was a challenging, fast paced environment and enjoyed working there. The professor with whom I worked was an open minded person, he was ready to accept the wildest of the ideas. Working along with 10 other students added up to the steep learning curve.
cons: A dollar or two higher than the minimum hourly wage. That is bad!

pros: nice lab, nice people, nice location. Feel great to work with nice people. The cost in the area is low.
cons:
No money left to frame second degree
Only small percentage of PhDs actually go on to be featured in History Channel specials
Could be a lot of work
Will have to say thesis topic out loud
Impossible to truly relive glory days of co-ed madrigal singers
Could lead to career in academia

review_title: Excellent Benefits and Vacation, Decent Pay
pros: Great retirement plan, great benefits, and plenty of vacation time right off the bat. Excellent new rec center is free to employees. After three years, free tuition for you and your family.
cons: There is not much room for advancement, and the pay is marginal at best, without much hope of a raise or bonuses.

pros: Research experience gives a close working relation with the  supervisors and advisors. You get to pick a project and develop it into the direction you want to. Very good hands-on experience.
cons: The way they process the SURF position should be more systematic and organized. They only mailed the decision way past the deadline they promised. Very inconvenient.

pros: Working load is OK, not too much, Highly depends on who you are working with. General a good place to work.
cons: TA salary has not been raised for several years. That's now between the level of 1st year and 2nd year graduate students.

review_title: Great for Undergrads, Not That Great for Grads
pros: Lots of hands-on experience. Very friendly environment. Great engineering know-how. Young professors. Great gym.
cons: There isn't a graduate school culture. As a grad student a social scientific environment is important and WPI is too small to provide that volume and throughput.

review_title: It is a small engineering-focused college but strives to expand and improve what it can offer.
pros: I got to learn quite some new skills and met some nice people.
cons: Some rules are so old and awkward yet still effective.

review_title: Great School To Learn About Computer Science
pros:
- Computer Science Program started off being tailored to graduate students
- Many professors with esteemed background
- Combination between research and practice school
cons: - School is tailored towards the undergraduates, so not many opportunities are given to graduate students

pros: You go to graduate school for free, certainly nice.  Get to review a lot of material and teaching helps reinforce concepts.
cons: Some professors may demand more of your time than is required.

pros: Nice pay. People are nice to each other.
cons: I don't see good moving up ladders.

review_title: My experience overall has been pretty ok; sometimes it can be a little strained.
pros: Currently, it helps a lot to work close to school since academics take up most of my time.
cons: As a student, classes and projects can get in the way of work, so it can be hard to maintain a steady work schedule.

pros: Depending on the Professor, flexible hours, stable work environment
cons: can be much higher than 40 hrs per week, intermittent strange hours due to experiments

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Worcester, MA
pros: Strong academic programs and campus initiatives, student project work and research, community feel, Higher Ed role model, continual growth in the city of Worcester
cons: Average pay grades, lack of diversity on faculty and staff, promotions based more on time than merit, vacation time doesn't kick in until a year of service has been completed

job_title: Teaching Assistant and Researcher in Worcester, MA
pros: Helpful, motivated peers.  Good amount of resources to accomplish your job.
cons: In the end, still a money driven business.  As a teaching assistant the whole way through your degree, you have to work your butt off to make it through.

job_title: Laboratory Manager, Department of Fire Protection Engineering in Pascoag, RI
pros: Working with the students. If you are fortunate to have a good dept. head WPI can be a great place to work in many other ways as well.
cons: Staff does not receive support from management or administration. Tenured faculty are not held to the ethical standard WPI boasts. They are allowed to waste money, abuse staff and participate in inappropriate activities without repercussions.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Worcester, MA
pros:
Great engineering and research environment.
Nice campus.
UMass Medical School near - many projects are available.
Great if you like to teach too.
cons:
Regardless how much you try, or like teaching, you will never become a tenure track teaching faculty.
You are treated like a lower life form (compared to teaching faculty)

pros: You are among highly qualified faculty and there is lot to learn from them. Adding a high class education and degree to your resume.
cons: primarily an under graduate school. facilities are catered mostly towards the under graduates.

review_title: Very Comfortable and supportive work environment.
pros: Flexible syllabus, Lot of research to do, college provides facilities to work on research and other student development facilities such as career development center. campus events. Nice professor.
cons: Lot of campus events on campus, may not be able to participate in all.

pros: a nice and quiet engineering school (as long as things go ok and you do not run into any problems). Benefits were ok.
cons: Not supportive of their staff: I ran into problems and had bad experience with the HR, overall I was not happy with the HR and how the problem was handled. Pay was low and the campus was way too quiet for my taste. Overall I did not have a good social experience on campus.

pros: It has a number of talent students, researchers, and faculties. It has a good education and industry reputation in regional area.
cons: It is kindof rural, and does not have many fancy stuff outside campus. But it is closed to Boston.

review_title: Small engineering school in central mass
pros: Great staff and easy to interact with everyone
cons: Some of the teachers care much more about research than their students. The responsibility then falls upon the teaching assistant to help out the students.

review_title: Center for Holographic Studies and Laser micro-mechaTronics
pros: Great experience with state of the art optical metrology techniques.
cons: WPI currently does not have an Optical Engineering program, however, is in the processes of creating one.  When that will be offered is unknown.

review_title: Overall a good place to work as a graduate student
job_title: Aircraft Maintenance Supervisor in Worcester, MA
pros:
- Nice research facilities
- Salary is enough for the area
- Helpful faculty
cons: - Like most graduate schools, your faculty mentor makes all the difference.  Some are great, some not so great.

review_title: Small university focus on undergraduate study
pros: a lot of project for undergraduates
cons: should pay more attention to graduate students

review_title: Great atmosphere to work in with a lot of opportunity in research and devlopment
pros: Small campus, great location, many knowledgeable professors to work with and learn about their resesarch
cons: Worcester can be dangerous at night

pros: PIs are very reasonable and don't ask to pull several all-nighters in a row
cons: Research is kinda sluggish compared to other institutions

pros: A hard working, savvy group that has great out-of-work unity. Strong leadership and and solid work from everyone.
cons: A bit insular and difficult to work with as an outsider. Notable miscommunication and payroll issues

review_title: Good environment, but unfortunately had a bad manager and no opportunity to move up
pros: Good people, good environment, decent benefits
cons: Can make more money elsewhere, not all managers are good there, but some were

review_title: Good to explore different fields you might be interested in
pros:
- Good mentorship
- Ability to adquire experience in new fields you might be interested in
cons:
- Limited budget
- You work independently so it might not be for everyone

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: Interesting work, good relation with professors
cons: Can be time demanding. Especially if you are pursuing PhD which takes a lot out from you.

pros: flexible working time sheet. great interaction with fellow students. can improve relationship with advisor and professor.
cons: low salary, sometimes can be very busy. working experience depends on professor and varies a lot.

pros: People are smart and willing to help you solve the problem
cons: Class size are getting bigger and bigger

pros: They were extremely fair and always helped me schedule hours alongside schoolwork.  They are very understanding of having a flexible schedule.
cons: There is no cons to this job it was a part-time internship.

job_title: Research and Teaching Assistant in Worcester, MA
pros: WPI has a good campus environment, and all the staffs here is very nice.
cons: The scale of the school is not very big.

review_title: Worcester Polytechnic Institute is a diverse Institution that strives on greatness and excellence.
pros: There is always room for progression. Here at WPI the community and employees are a family.
cons: I have no cons at WPI.

pros: As a student Assistant, you have Very flexible hours and no office times
cons: If you are not fully committed to helping the students, you may not have time to conduct class tutorials etc

pros: Enough for daily expenses and support my research. Beautiful place to live and work, Please are really nice.
cons: A lot of work. Time arrangement seems to be hard.

pros:
-Very friendly environment
-Great management
-Laid back environment
-Helpful management and staff
cons: -Not a lot of room for advancement

pros: People are all very kind, really a good college
cons: The college might be a little small, the public relation can be better

pros: WPI is a great engineering university and has good benefits for employees. Employer match to 401K is great.
cons: Employee share of health care benefit has increased.

pros:
flexible schedule
faculty genuinely care about the success of their students and the university
great place to work and good supervisor
cons:
life and work balance
growing pains as the enrollment grows

pros: The projects are varied and easier to switch between the projects.
cons: The pay is really low but still great for a part time job

review_title: Working as an undergrad student assistant
pros: Helping peers and getting additional practice with material from previously completed classes.
cons: Limited to working only 10 hours or less per week.

pros: Great chance to practice what I learned here. Nice people.
cons: Not that I can think of

pros: Getting state of the art research with the possibility to collaborate with high-end institutions.
cons: Post-doc is not well paid compared to the quality of the work

pros: awesome place to work  and good school
cons: small school and small campus to work in

pros:
Good and collaborative environment to work in

Was amazing to work with students
cons:
Needs to spend on infrastructure
No good benefits
Boss not as helpful

pros: Friendly Staff, good work as a student
cons: Sometimes hard to juggle when you have finals going on for yourself

pros: Lots of fun and sociable student workers and staff members. Student staffs are treated well!
cons: Sometimes no one does work. Not the most professional work place.

job_title: Administrative Assistant V in Worcester, MA
pros: Paid time off between Christmas and New Year's without using vacation time.
cons: The pay here for staff is horrible.

review_title: Great place to work and advance
job_title: Administrative Assistant/Office Manager in Worcester, MA
pros: Amazing benefits and atmosphere.  Very supportive management and team.
cons: Salary is on the low side

pros: Not many hours usually, depends on the class though
cons: Sometimes teachers are disorganized and you have to pick up their slack

review_title: Study in WPI for Master Degree
pros: Good Education, Some very impressive course: Israel phenomenon. Good POI
cons: Located in small town, limited access to broader atmosphere.

review_title: Nice place to work. Great people
job_title: Control Desk Staff in Worcester, MA
pros: you can take classes while you work here. Student wages are pretty good.
cons: Hours aren't very much. Sometimes boring.

pros: Good school, good community and good environment for doing research
cons: I see that there is no disadvantage of studying here

pros: Good relationship with professors and you can make great connections. Exceptional quality of education
cons: The pay scale is not that great

job_title: Assistant Teaching PRofessor in Worcester, MA
pros: fun and inspiring work and students
cons: poor pay,  you are disposable, no vote @ faculty meetings,  little opportunity

pros: Great company culture, remote working is available, benefits and holiday is great
cons: No room for growth. Low pay

pros: Good place to work, if you work for a nice professor for grad course.
cons: If undergrad course, it is pretty hard.

pros: A very interesting place to learn about a lot of interesting subjects.
cons: At times, the atmosphere can be a little political.

pros: Great learning experience with decent payment for college student.
cons: Hard to follow as first year student,.

pros: Small university so people may be well connected.
cons: Small university so sometimes resources (especially human connection) can be limited.

job_title: Software Developer Internship in Worcester, MA
pros: work with smart guys and learned technology in web developing
cons: too many meeting every week

pros: Lot of learning. Great pay.
cons: Depends on the professor you are working for.

pros: Part time, lets you pick what you want to work on.
cons: Gateway is a long walk in winter

pros: You learn a lot and the faculty are willing to take the time to teach
cons: The pay isn’t the greatest

pros: Friendly environment, respectful employees, small community.

job_title: Student Grounds Worker in Worcester, MA
pros: Learn new skills for landscaping and work in the sun all day
cons: Early start at 6 am

pros: Great people, education and time off!
cons: Salaries are very low in general for administrative positions.

pros: strong school in the field of science and engineering

pros: Is a very good opportunities to work with world class professors

pros: Excellent exposure and great opportunities to learn.

cons: less salary.More exposure is needed

pros: My advisor is great and helpful and wants me to succeed

pros: It is a great place to advance academically and professionally

pros: very nice, make a lots of friend

job_title: IT Help Desk in Worcester, MA
pros: Great place to work at.
